Recipe.title: Bath Canning: How-To
Recipe.Description:
Usually, when you cook food, it needs to be consumed in short period of time, or it will get spoiled. However, some foods can be bottled and stored for a long time, years in some cases.
However, just putting the food in bottles is not sufficient. You have to do "canning". Basically, canning kills practically all of the bacteria, etc. and creates an air-tight seal.

ingredient.name: Canning Bottles of the appropriate size
ingredient.nameNote: For example: Mason, Kerr, Ball, etc.

ingredient.name: Canning-appropriate Food
ingredient.nameNote: This may include sauces, jams, jellies, fruit in syrup, etc.

ingredient.name: New Lids for the Bottles
ingredient.nameNote: Re-using old lids tends to cause a lot of failed seals.

section.instruction: Fill Bath Canner with water to about the depth necessary to cover the bottles that will be used.
Place Bath Canner on stove burner set to high and bring water to a boil.

Place clean, empty bottles into the boiling water so that they are completely covered for 5 minutes.
(Bottles must be placed upright and side-by-side. For example, with a standard sized Bath Canner, this can be done with 7 quart-sized bottles at a time.)
Remove bottles from water and let dry for about 1 minute.
Place boiling-hot food into bottles, filling to about 1 inch from the top.
Put Lids and Rings onto the bottles and tighten securely.

Gently place filled Bottles into the Bath Canner and bring water back to a boil.
(Again, Bottles must be placed upright and side-by-side. For example, with a standard sized Bath Canner, this can be done with 7 quart-sized bottles at a time.)
Boil for the appropriate amount of time for the recipe. (Refer to the specific recipe.)
Remove the bottles from the Bath Canner and set on a towel on a flat surface.
Let cool for several hours. (Overnight is good.)
Once cooled, make sure the lids have sealed by pressing down on the center of the lids. If they pop in, then pop back out, the bottle did not seal.

Notes.note: When filling the jars, use care not to get any food on the mouth of the jar. If this does occur, carefully clean the mouth of the jar with a clean cloth.
The easiest way to keep the mouths of the jars clean while filling is to use a wide-mouthed funnel built specifically for canning.

The food in bottles that don't seal is still edible, but you cannot store it!
The options are:
Eat the contents of the bottle normally.
Follow the canning process starting over at Step 1.
